item.title: My little game won't work
item.dc:creator: @cows_be_sacred cows_be_sacred
item.description:
@cows_be_sacred wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch™, post:1, topic:310726”]Yes despite my name, I don’t know any Java. I want to get into it, so I took a class at school. We’re doing Dark Basic, but it’s kind of a bore(We’re planning to do Java later on in the year).

I decided to make a game to test out a package I downloaded and also to understand arrays better(they always get me). I got so frustrated that I started commenting on the order that things happen, to see where I could have gone wrong, even went to the trouble of making long names for my variables to actually see if I was using the right one.

Problem:
If the first attempt by the user is George, then they get it right, program ends, done.
But if the first attempt is wrong, and second attempt is right, it says that both attempts are wrong.

Can’t be certain on where the problem lies, but I’m thinking between lines 79-90
Maybe the Boolean is updated before it says its right, and when they get it wrong it isn’t updated in the FOR loop. I’m stumped. Can anyone help?

(It’s not done yet, so the hints part doesn’t work)

[code=java]import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import org.apache.commons.lang.ArrayUtils;
//import java.util.Scanner;
//import java.util.Arrays;

public class Package {

/*

Title: Guessing Game

Author: GeorgeG

Purpose: To test out ArrayUtils package.

What it does:

The user has to guess the programmers name, George.
The programmer also has a nickname, Geo.
If the user guesses either; George OR Geo, then he wins the game.
If NOT, then he still keeps guessing.

*/

//My name & nickname
static String[] whatUserHasToGuess = {"George", "Geo"};

//What the user inputs; null;
static String whatUserInputs;

//If the user types in h and presses enter, it gives them a hint.
static String[] hints = {"It has 6 letters", "One of the U.S Presidents", "Curious......?", "ITS GEORGE"};

//Gets what the user inputed TO String
static BufferedReader input = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));

//Checks against the array to see if what the user inputed matches whats in the array
static boolean correct = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs);

//User has attempts
static int attempts;


public static void main(String[] args) {

  		/*

	Prints out starting lines of the game		

	
	*/

	startingLines();
  		/*

	Allows the user to type something in
	In turn, it returns:
	-String whatUserInputs TO whatever the user typed	

	
	*/

	input();
	
	/*

	If the boolean contains turns out to be true (that whatever the user typed is in the array)
	then the user has won the game.

	But if the user typed in something that isn't in the array,
	It will attempts++ (only 10 chances), and give them a chance
	to type in a new name 

	*/
	
	//correct();
	//wrong();


}

public static void startingLines() {
	p("Guessing Game");
	newLine();
	p("Let's play the guessing game!");
	newLine();
	p("My name is ______");
	newLine();
	p("Try to guess my name, I'll give you a hint!");
	newLine();
	p("Common name in the U.S");
	newLine();
	p("Type h for a hint");
	newLine();
	p("You only have 10 chances");
	newLine();
}

public static void input() {
	try {
		whatUserInputs = input.readLine(); //Makes it into a String
		correct = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs);
			if(correct) { 
				correct(); 
			} else {
				wrong();
			}
	} catch (IOException ioe) {
		ioe.printStackTrace();
	}
}

public static void correct() {
	if(correct == true) {
		p("Congratulations, you've guessed my name correctly!");
		newLine();
		System.exit(0);
	}

}

public static void wrong() {
	if(correct == false) {
		for (attempts = 0; attempts < 9; attempts++) { //0 Counts
			p("You've guessed my name wrong, try again");
			newLine();
			input();
		}
	}
}

public static void p(String s) {
	System.out.print(s);
}

public static void newLine() {
	System.out.println("\n");
}

}[/code]
*Updated ^^… again.[/quote]
Just a question but, is this from head first java? I’m almost there

Read full topic

item.title: My little game won't work
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

I didn’t copy what he put, it was wrong. I edited my post, so the remark about it being wrong isn’t there anymore.

I added the if condition in input() to check if the user input was correct or not.

What the hell is the point of me putting
correct() & wrong() within main, if you just need input() to check.

Here it works:

public static void input() { try { whatUserInputs = input.readLine(); //Makes it into a String correct = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs); if(correct) { correct(); } else { wrong(); } } catch (IOException ioe) { ioe.printStackTrace(); } }

But if I put the correct bit in main, it doesn’t work.

item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

Oh god, and are you serious, Most of what I typed could of been simplified to that!?!? Wow, I got a lot to learn then lol.

EDIT:

I got it to work :).

Had to think what the computer was doing and add the if in there.

public static void input() { try { whatUserInputs = input.readLine(); //Makes it into a String correct = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs); if(correct) { correct(); } } catch (IOException ioe) { ioe.printStackTrace();

Not sure if it’s the ‘right’ way to do it, but it worked. But I also would like to learn what you consider the right way is.

Is this what you were saying? Where I should add the conditional statement.

Thank you both for all your help :).

Read full topic

item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

example: [code]public class Main {

private static boolean equals(String str) {
    for (String s : names) {
        if (s.equalsIgnoreCase(str)) {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    while(!equals(System.console().readLine("Guess my name: "))) {
        System.out.println("Incorrect guess!");
    }
    System.out.println("You successfully guessed my name!");
}

private static String[] names = { "George", "Geo" };

}[/code]

item.title: My little game won't work
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:2, topic:310726”]you are hiding the contains field with local variables

for example input() should be

public static void input() { try { whatUserInputs = input.readLine(); //Makes it into a String contains = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs); } catch (IOException ioe) { ioe.printStackTrace(); } }

you should also remove the same thing in your main method[/quote]

I really don’t get what you mean by the local variables are hiding contains.

Scratch that, got you.

there, the user's input is read in input() but not compared to see if the new input was correct or incorrect, so you should have a nested conditional statement within the first one. so you should have

But in input()

It updates the Boolean when the user has put in a new name

whatUserInputs = input.readLine(); //Makes it into a String correct = ArrayUtils.contains(whatUserHasToGuess, whatUserInputs);

Doesn’t it check it there? So if it turns out its true, wouldn’t it go to true and they were successful?

Thank you for that method by the way.

EDIT:

Sorry, I renamed my variables for clarity. contains = correct.

item.title: My little game won't work
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

first of all let me say that your poor use of functions has left a tear in my eye,

your problem lies within the fact that after the user has erroneously guessed the name, there is no revision on whether the next input is correct or not. see, at first you had:

if (contains) { //etc } so you did revise whether the user guessed the string correctly; but only in the first try. if the user did not guess it correctly, it is passed to execute this:

} else if(!contains) { for (attempts = 0; attempts < 9; attempts++) { //0 Counts p("You've guessed my name wrong, try again"); newLine(); input(); } }
there, the user’s input is read in input() but not compared to see if the new input was correct or incorrect, so you should have a nested conditional statement within the first one. so you should have

if(contains) { p("Congratulations, you've guessed my name correctly!"); newLine(); } else if(!contains) { for (attempts = 0; attempts < 9; attempts++) { //0 Counts p("You've guessed my name wrong, try again"); newLine(); input(); /*revise here whether the new user input contains one of the strings in the array*/ } }

by the way, its a very bad idea for you to be using an external class just for something as easy as array.contains. make your own function:

boolean contains(Object[] o, Object obj) { for (Object ob : o) { if (ob.equals(obj)) { return true; } } return false; } that is just a generic function, use a class-specific function for classes like string which override equals()

Read full topic
